frameDefinitions: A Believer has faith in a piece of Content or an Element  which fits into a religious belief system made up of many articles of faith.
An Item belongs to a Category, as (often implicitly) conceived of by a Cognizer.
A Cognizer has a piece of Content in their model of the world.
In this frame, which is a  part of the Trial sequence, a Judge gives a Finding with respect to the Charges against the Defendant in a particular Case.
A Cognizer thinks that the Information given by a particular Source is correct.
This frame concerns a Cognizer's certainty about the correctness of beliefs  or expectations.
frameExamples: Do Muslims <t>believe</t> in the virgin birth of Jesus?
To me this <t>counts</t> as historical fiction because it is based on real events.
Your boss is <t>aware</t> of your commitment.
He was <t>convicted</t> of fraud by Judge Judy.
Lermontov was <t>certain</t> he would come to the party.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Believer</fen> is the person whose religious beliefs are in question.
The <fen>Content</fen> is the object of the <fen>Believer</fen>'s religious conviction. <fen>Content</fen> can be expressed as a finite clause or in a in-PP Complement.
<fen>Role</fen> is a  function that an Element of the faith is believed to serve.
A predefined, fixed idea to which reference is made throughout the belief system.
This is the entity which is is an instance of a particular <fen>Category</fen>. Typically, the <fen>Item</fen> is expressed as the external argument.

This frame element expresses a general type or class of which the <fen>Item</fen> is considered an instance. Typically, it is expressed in a prepositional phrase headed by <ment>as</ment> or <ment>under</ment>.

This frame element expresses properties of the <fen>Item</fen> which is used as a basis for categorization. <fen>Criteria</fen> are the general dimensions along which <fen>Item</fen>s can potentially differ from one another and hence, fall into different <fen>Category</fen>s. For example, a paint sample can be classified <ment>by color</ment> or <ment>by finish (matte or gloss)</ment>; if they are classified by color, one can be classified <ment>as orange</ment> and another <ment>as red</ment>. The <fen>Criteria</fen> role is typically expressed as a PP headed by <ment>by</ment>, or as a complex PP of the form <ment>on the basis of...</ment>:
This Frame Element marks expressions that indicate when a certain Categorization holds.

The <fen>Cognizer</fen> is the person whose awareness of phenomena is at question. With a target verb or adjective the <fen>Cognizer</fen> is generally expressed as an External Argument with the <fen>Content</fen> expressed as an Object or Complement.
The <fen>Content</fen> is the object of the <fen>Cognizer</fen>'s awareness. <fen>Content</fen> can be expressed as a direct object or in a PP Complement.
Some verbs in this frame allow a <fen>Topic</fen> to be expressed in about-PPs.
<fen>Expressor</fen> is the body part that reveals the <fen>Cognizer</fen>'s state to the observer.
The time interval during which the <fen>Cognizer</fen> is aware of the <fen>Content</fen>.
The <fen>Judge</fen> (which may be the jury, judge, magistrate or court) decides on the <fen>Finding</fen>.
This role identifies the outcome of the <fen>Judge</fen>'s deliberation or consideration. Many LUs in this frame incorporate this FE.
The person who stands accused of a crime and is subject to the verdict.
This role refers to the <fen>Charges</fen> with respect to which the verdict is being given.
The <fen>Case</fen> on which the verdict is being given.
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.
The <fen>Cognizer</fen> is the person who has an opinion about the reliability of a <fen>Information_source</fen> or the <fen>Information</fen> from the <fen>Information_source</fen>.
An object or action associated with the <fen>Cognizer</fen> which is so affected by the <fen>Cognizer</fen>'s belief that it reveals the <fen>Cognizer</fen>'s state.
The individual that gives Information to the <fen>Cognizer</fen>.
The text or speech which the <fen>Cognizer</fen> has heard and evaluates the truth of.
The <fen>Cognizer</fen> is the person whose certainty or uncertainty is at issue.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the entity that a <fen>Cognizer</fen> has a certain/uncertain belief about.
The <fen>Content</fen> denotes the mental content that the <fen>Cognizer</fen> is certain or uncertain about.
The <fen>Expressor</fen> is the body part or action by a body part that conveys the mental state of  the <fen>Cognizer</fen>.
listRoleExamples: A Christian believes <fex>that Jesus of Nazareth was a prophet</fex>.
If a person believes in Jesus <fex>as his Saviour</fex>, he can he baptized.
To me, <fex>finding this</fex> is tantamount to finding the fabeled El Dorado.
I'd say that this book counts <fex>as fiction</fex>.
If it counts as knowledge in part <fex>on the basis of justification from another source</fex>, it must be in part based on that source
Fold in inflation and what counted as shameful gouging <fex>20 years ago</fex> is today called charging what the market will bear.
<fex>Your boss</fex> is aware of your commitment.
Your boss is aware <fex>of your commitment</fex>.

Yet there is no evidence that Mr. Parrish was cognizant <fex>at the time of the signing
of the notes</fex> that the clauses in issue were present.
Her trustworthy <fex>eyes</fex> revealed that I was in no danger.
America trusted <fex>his declaration</fex> , to their detriment .
<fex>Marcel</fex> was sure that she had seen Eldridge on the balcony.
She talked of quests , of finding this absurd religious character , but he was unsure <fex>of her conviction</fex>.
I am sure <fex>that we'll arrive on time</fex>.
She caught sight of her mother's dubious <fex>expression</fex>.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: "The Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans"
